trans-unit.source: Restrict access to networks with Cisco ISE | Microsoft Intune
trans-unit.target: Restrict access to networks with Cisco ISE | Microsoft Intune

trans-unit.source: Use Cisco ISE with Intune so that devices are Intune enrolled and policy compliant before they access Wi-Fi and VPN that are controlled by Cisco ISE.
trans-unit.target: Use Cisco ISE with Intune so that devices are Intune enrolled and policy compliant before they access Wi-Fi and VPN that are controlled by Cisco ISE.

trans-unit.source: Using Cisco ISE with Microsoft Intune
trans-unit.target: Using Cisco ISE with Microsoft Intune

trans-unit.source: Intune integration with Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE) allows you to author network policies in your ISE environment by using the Intune device-enrollment and compliance state.
trans-unit.target: Intune integration with Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE) allows you to author network policies in your ISE environment by using the Intune device-enrollment and compliance state.

trans-unit.source: You can use these policies to ensure that access to your company network is restricted to devices that are managed by Intune and compliant with Intune policies.
trans-unit.target: You can use these policies to ensure that access to your company network is restricted to devices that are managed by Intune and compliant with Intune policies.

trans-unit.source: Configuration steps
trans-unit.target: Configuration steps

trans-unit.source: To enable this integration, you don’t need to do any setup in your Intune tenant.
trans-unit.target: To enable this integration, you don’t need to do any setup in your Intune tenant.

trans-unit.source: You will need to provide permissions to your Cisco ISE server to access your Intune tenant.
trans-unit.target: You will need to provide permissions to your Cisco ISE server to access your Intune tenant.

trans-unit.source: After that's done, the rest of the setup happens in your Cisco ISE server.
trans-unit.target: After that's done, the rest of the setup happens in your Cisco ISE server.

trans-unit.source: This article gives you instructions on providing your ISE server with permissions to access your Intune tenant.
trans-unit.target: This article gives you instructions on providing your ISE server with permissions to access your Intune tenant.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Manage the certificates
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Manage the certificates

trans-unit.source: Export the certificate from the Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) console, then import it into the Trusted Certificates store of the ISE console:
trans-unit.target: Export the certificate from the Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) console, then import it into the Trusted Certificates store of the ISE console:

trans-unit.source: Internet Explorer 11
trans-unit.target: Internet Explorer 11

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Run Internet Explorer as an administrator, and sign in to the Azure AD console.
trans-unit.target: Run Internet Explorer as an administrator, and sign in to the Azure AD console.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: Choose the lock icon in the address bar and choose **View certificates**.
trans-unit.target: Choose the lock icon in the address bar and choose **View certificates**.

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: On the **Details** tab of the certificate properties, choose **Copy to file**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Details** tab of the certificate properties, choose **Copy to file**.

trans-unit.source: d.
trans-unit.target: d.

trans-unit.source: In the **Certificate export wizard** welcome page, choose **Next**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Certificate export wizard** welcome page, choose **Next**.

trans-unit.source: e.
trans-unit.target: e.

trans-unit.source: On the **Export file format** page, leave the default, **DER encoded binary x.509 (.CER)**, and choose **Next**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Export file format** page, leave the default, **DER encoded binary x.509 (.CER)**, and choose **Next**.

trans-unit.source: f.
trans-unit.target: f.

trans-unit.source: On the **File to export** page, choose **Browse** to pick a location in which to save the file, and provide a file name.
trans-unit.target: On the **File to export** page, choose **Browse** to pick a location in which to save the file, and provide a file name.

trans-unit.source: Though it seems like you’re picking a file to export, you’re actually naming the file that the exported certificate will be saved to.
trans-unit.target: Though it seems like you’re picking a file to export, you’re actually naming the file that the exported certificate will be saved to.

trans-unit.source: Choose **Next** > **Finish**.
trans-unit.target: Choose **Next** > **Finish**.

trans-unit.source: g.
trans-unit.target: g.

trans-unit.source: From within the ISE console, import the Intune certificate (the file you exported) into the **Trusted Certificates** store.
trans-unit.target: From within the ISE console, import the Intune certificate (the file you exported) into the **Trusted Certificates** store.

trans-unit.source: Safari
trans-unit.target: Safari

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the Azure AD console.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure AD console.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: Choose the lock icon > **More information**.
trans-unit.target: Choose the lock icon > **More information**.

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: Choose **View certificate** > **Details**.
trans-unit.target: Choose **View certificate** > **Details**.

trans-unit.source: d.
trans-unit.target: d.

trans-unit.source: Choose the certificate, and then choose **Export**.
trans-unit.target: Choose the certificate, and then choose **Export**.

trans-unit.source: e.
trans-unit.target: e.

trans-unit.source: From within the ISE console, import the Intune certificate (the file you exported) into the **Trusted Certificates** store.
trans-unit.target: From within the ISE console, import the Intune certificate (the file you exported) into the **Trusted Certificates** store.

trans-unit.source: Check the expiration date of the certificate, as you will have to export and import a new certificate when this one expires.
trans-unit.target: Check the expiration date of the certificate, as you will have to export and import a new certificate when this one expires.

trans-unit.source: Obtain a self-signed cert from ISE
trans-unit.target: Obtain a self-signed cert from ISE

trans-unit.source: In the ISE console, go to **Administration** > **Certificates** > **System Certificates** > **Generate Self Signed Certificate**.
trans-unit.target: In the ISE console, go to **Administration** > **Certificates** > **System Certificates** > **Generate Self Signed Certificate**.

trans-unit.source: Export the self-signed certificate.
trans-unit.target: Export the self-signed certificate.

trans-unit.source: In a text editor, edit the exported certificate: [comment]: <> I'd rather not put a period at the end of these two statements, I think it could be confusing.
trans-unit.target: In a text editor, edit the exported certificate: [comment]: <> I'd rather not put a period at the end of these two statements, I think it could be confusing.

trans-unit.source: Delete ** -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----**
trans-unit.target: Delete ** -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----**

trans-unit.source: Delete ** -----END CERTIFICATE-----**
trans-unit.target: Delete ** -----END CERTIFICATE-----**

trans-unit.source: Ensure all of the text is a single line
trans-unit.target: Ensure all of the text is a single line

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create an app for ISE in your Azure AD tenant
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create an app for ISE in your Azure AD tenant

trans-unit.source: In the Azure AD console, choose **Applications** > **Add an Application** > **Add an application my organization is developing**.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure AD console, choose **Applications** > **Add an Application** > **Add an application my organization is developing**.

trans-unit.source: Provide a name and a URL for the app.
trans-unit.target: Provide a name and a URL for the app.

trans-unit.source: The URL could be your company website.
trans-unit.target: The URL could be your company website.

trans-unit.source: Download the app manifest (a JSON file).
trans-unit.target: Download the app manifest (a JSON file).

trans-unit.source: Edit the manifest JSON file.
trans-unit.target: Edit the manifest JSON file.

trans-unit.source: In the setting called **keyCredentials**, provide the edited certificate text from Step 1 as the setting value.
trans-unit.target: In the setting called **keyCredentials**, provide the edited certificate text from Step 1 as the setting value.

trans-unit.source: Save the file without changing its name.
trans-unit.target: Save the file without changing its name.

trans-unit.source: Provide your app with permissions to Microsoft Graph and the Microsoft Intune API.
trans-unit.target: Provide your app with permissions to Microsoft Graph and the Microsoft Intune API.

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: For Microsoft Graph, choose the following:
trans-unit.target: For Microsoft Graph, choose the following:

trans-unit.source: **Application permissions**: Read directory data
trans-unit.target: **Application permissions**: Read directory data

trans-unit.source: **Delegated permissions**:
trans-unit.target: **Delegated permissions**:

trans-unit.source: Access user’s data anytime
trans-unit.target: Access user’s data anytime

trans-unit.source: Sign users in
trans-unit.target: Sign users in

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: For the Microsoft Intune API, in **Application permissions**, choose **Get device state and compliance from Intune**.
trans-unit.target: For the Microsoft Intune API, in **Application permissions**, choose **Get device state and compliance from Intune**.

trans-unit.source: Choose **View Endpoints** and copy the following values for use in configuring ISE settings:
trans-unit.target: Choose **View Endpoints** and copy the following values for use in configuring ISE settings:

trans-unit.source: Value in Azure AD portal
trans-unit.target: Value in Azure AD portal

trans-unit.source: Corresponding field in ISE portal
trans-unit.target: Corresponding field in ISE portal

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure AD Graph API endpoint
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure AD Graph API endpoint

trans-unit.source: Auto Discovery URL
trans-unit.target: Auto Discovery URL

trans-unit.source: Oauth 2.0 Token endpoint
trans-unit.target: Oauth 2.0 Token endpoint

trans-unit.source: Token Issuing URL
trans-unit.target: Token Issuing URL

trans-unit.source: Update your code with your Client ID
trans-unit.target: Update your code with your Client ID

trans-unit.source: Client ID
trans-unit.target: Client ID

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Upload the self-signed certificate from ISE into the ISE app you created in Azure AD
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Upload the self-signed certificate from ISE into the ISE app you created in Azure AD

trans-unit.source: Get the base64 encoded cert value and thumbprint from a .cer X509 public cert file.
trans-unit.target: Get the base64 encoded cert value and thumbprint from a .cer X509 public cert file.

trans-unit.source: This example uses PowerShell:
trans-unit.target: This example uses PowerShell:

trans-unit.source: Store the values for $base64Thumbprint, $base64Value and $keyid, to be used in the next step.
trans-unit.target: Store the values for $base64Thumbprint, $base64Value and $keyid, to be used in the next step.

trans-unit.source: Upload the certificate through the manifest file.
trans-unit.target: Upload the certificate through the manifest file.

trans-unit.source: Log in to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com)
trans-unit.target: Log in to the [Azure Management Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com)

trans-unit.source: In to the Azure AD snap-in find the application that you want to configure with an X.509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: In to the Azure AD snap-in find the application that you want to configure with an X.509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: Download the application manifest file.
trans-unit.target: Download the application manifest file.

trans-unit.source: Replace the empty “KeyCredentials”: [], property with the following JSON.
trans-unit.target: Replace the empty “KeyCredentials”: [], property with the following JSON.

trans-unit.source: The KeyCredentials complex type is documented in[Entity and complex type reference](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ad/graph/api/entity-and-complex-type-reference#KeyCredentialType).
trans-unit.target: The KeyCredentials complex type is documented in[Entity and complex type reference](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ad/graph/api/entity-and-complex-type-reference#KeyCredentialType).

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Save the change to the application manifest file.
trans-unit.target: Save the change to the application manifest file.

trans-unit.source: Upload the edited application manifest file through the Azure management mortal.
trans-unit.target: Upload the edited application manifest file through the Azure management mortal.

trans-unit.source: Optional: Download the manifest again, to check that your X.509 cert is present on the application.
trans-unit.target: Optional: Download the manifest again, to check that your X.509 cert is present on the application.

trans-unit.source: KeyCredentials is a collection, so you can upload multiple X.509 certificates for rollover scenarios, or delete certficates in compromise scenarios.
trans-unit.target: KeyCredentials is a collection, so you can upload multiple X.509 certificates for rollover scenarios, or delete certficates in compromise scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Configure ISE Settings
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Configure ISE Settings

trans-unit.source: In the ISE admin console, provide these setting values:
trans-unit.target: In the ISE admin console, provide these setting values:

trans-unit.source: **Server Type**: Mobile Device Manager
trans-unit.target: **Server Type**: Mobile Device Manager

trans-unit.source: **Authentication type**: OAuth – Client Credentials
trans-unit.target: **Authentication type**: OAuth – Client Credentials

trans-unit.source: **Auto Discovery**: Yes
trans-unit.target: **Auto Discovery**: Yes

trans-unit.source: **Auto Discover URL**: *Enter the value from Step 1.*
trans-unit.target: **Auto Discover URL**: *Enter the value from Step 1.*

trans-unit.source: **Client ID**: *Enter the value from Step 1.*
trans-unit.target: **Client ID**: *Enter the value from Step 1.*

trans-unit.source: **Token issuing URL**: *Enter the value from Step 1.*
trans-unit.target: **Token issuing URL**: *Enter the value from Step 1.*

trans-unit.source: Information shared between your Intune tenant and your Cisco ISE server
trans-unit.target: Information shared between your Intune tenant and your Cisco ISE server

trans-unit.source: This table lists the information that is shared between your Intune tenant and your Cisco ISE server for devices that are managed by Intune.
trans-unit.target: This table lists the information that is shared between your Intune tenant and your Cisco ISE server for devices that are managed by Intune.

trans-unit.source: Property
trans-unit.target: Property

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: complianceState
trans-unit.target: complianceState

trans-unit.source: The true or false string that indicates whether the device is compliant or noncompliant.
trans-unit.target: The true or false string that indicates whether the device is compliant or noncompliant.

trans-unit.source: isManaged
trans-unit.target: isManaged

trans-unit.source: The true or false string that indicates whether the client is managed by Intune or not.
trans-unit.target: The true or false string that indicates whether the client is managed by Intune or not.

trans-unit.source: macAddress
trans-unit.target: macAddress

trans-unit.source: The MAC address of the device.
trans-unit.target: The MAC address of the device.

trans-unit.source: serialNumber
trans-unit.target: serialNumber

trans-unit.source: The serial number of the device.
trans-unit.target: The serial number of the device.

trans-unit.source: It applies only to iOS devices.
trans-unit.target: It applies only to iOS devices.

trans-unit.source: imei
trans-unit.target: imei

trans-unit.source: The IMEI (15 decimal digits: 14 digits plus a check digit) or IMEISV (16 digits) number includes information on the origin, model, and serial number of the device.
trans-unit.target: The IMEI (15 decimal digits: 14 digits plus a check digit) or IMEISV (16 digits) number includes information on the origin, model, and serial number of the device.

trans-unit.source: The structure of this number is specified in 3GPP TS 23.003.
trans-unit.target: The structure of this number is specified in 3GPP TS 23.003.

trans-unit.source: It applies only to devices with SIM cards.
trans-unit.target: It applies only to devices with SIM cards.

trans-unit.source: udid
trans-unit.target: udid

trans-unit.source: The Unique Device Identifier, which is a sequence of 40 letters and numbers.
trans-unit.target: The Unique Device Identifier, which is a sequence of 40 letters and numbers.

trans-unit.source: It is specific to iOS devices.
trans-unit.target: It is specific to iOS devices.

trans-unit.source: meid
trans-unit.target: meid

trans-unit.source: The mobile equipment identifier, which is a globally unique number that identifies a physical piece of CDMA mobile station equipment.
trans-unit.target: The mobile equipment identifier, which is a globally unique number that identifies a physical piece of CDMA mobile station equipment.

trans-unit.source: The number format is defined by the 3GPP2 report S. R0048.
trans-unit.target: The number format is defined by the 3GPP2 report S. R0048.

trans-unit.source: However, in practical terms, it can be seen as an IMEI, but with hexadecimal digits.
trans-unit.target: However, in practical terms, it can be seen as an IMEI, but with hexadecimal digits.

trans-unit.source: An MEID is 56 bits long (14 hex digits).
trans-unit.target: An MEID is 56 bits long (14 hex digits).

trans-unit.source: It consists of three fields, including an 8-bit regional code (RR), a 24-bit manufacturer code, and a 24-bit manufacturer-assigned serial number.
trans-unit.target: It consists of three fields, including an 8-bit regional code (RR), a 24-bit manufacturer code, and a 24-bit manufacturer-assigned serial number.

trans-unit.source: osVersion
trans-unit.target: osVersion

trans-unit.source: The operating system version for the device.
trans-unit.target: The operating system version for the device.

trans-unit.source: model
trans-unit.target: model

trans-unit.source: The device model.
trans-unit.target: The device model.

trans-unit.source: manufacturer
trans-unit.target: manufacturer

trans-unit.source: The device manufacturer.
trans-unit.target: The device manufacturer.

trans-unit.source: azureDeviceId
trans-unit.target: azureDeviceId

trans-unit.source: The device ID after it has workplace joined with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: The device ID after it has workplace joined with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: It is an empty GUID for devices that are not joined.
trans-unit.target: It is an empty GUID for devices that are not joined.

trans-unit.source: lastContactTimeUtc
trans-unit.target: lastContactTimeUtc

trans-unit.source: The date and time when the device last checked in with the Intune management service.
trans-unit.target: The date and time when the device last checked in with the Intune management service.

trans-unit.source: User experience
trans-unit.target: User experience

trans-unit.source: When a user attempts to access resources by using an unenrolled device, they receive a prompt to enroll, such as the one shown here:
trans-unit.target: When a user attempts to access resources by using an unenrolled device, they receive a prompt to enroll, such as the one shown here:

trans-unit.source: Example of enrollment prompt
trans-unit.target: Example of enrollment prompt

trans-unit.source: When a user chooses to enroll, they are redirected to the Intune enrollment process.
trans-unit.target: When a user chooses to enroll, they are redirected to the Intune enrollment process.

trans-unit.source: The user enrollment experience for Intune is described in these topics:
trans-unit.target: The user enrollment experience for Intune is described in these topics:

trans-unit.source: Enroll your Android device in Intune
trans-unit.target: Enroll your Android device in Intune

trans-unit.source: Enroll your iOS device in Intune
trans-unit.target: Enroll your iOS device in Intune

trans-unit.source: Enroll your Mac OS X device in Intune
trans-unit.target: Enroll your Mac OS X device in Intune

trans-unit.source: Enroll your Windows device in Intune
trans-unit.target: Enroll your Windows device in Intune

trans-unit.source: There is also a [downloadable set of enrollment instructions](https://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/End-user-Intune-enrollment-55dfd64a) that you can use to create customized guidance for your user experience.
trans-unit.target: There is also a [downloadable set of enrollment instructions](https://gallery.technet.microsoft.com/End-user-Intune-enrollment-55dfd64a) that you can use to create customized guidance for your user experience.

trans-unit.source: See also
trans-unit.target: See also
